messages: 6a8ca7ce228632a45b077b5398962bf2 (01:41): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: me thinks there's a bug with mozCurrentSampleOffset

6a8ca7ce228632a45b077b5398962bf2 (01:42): Not bad, but seems to *rarely* happen when the CPU is at 100%.
6a8ca7ce228632a45b077b5398962bf2 (01:42): like firefox skips an event.
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:43): so until html 5 and css 3 are supported, what should we do?

3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:44): well isn't it like 20 or 30 years away?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:45): have you done any googling or looking around regarding the support that is already present?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:47): you can use a decent chunk of it now with good support
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:48): although keep in mind that different browsers do have different levels of support for X feature

7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:50): I'm a Flash/iPhone developer, and I'm having much google failings trying to determine whether there's a good IDE/SDK/etc for developing HTML5... is anyone able to point me to something worth checking out?
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:50): I mean I could do the dev in notepad, but I've become rather accustomed to code completion and other such nifty tools :)
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:51): err..sorry, for developing in javascript/CANVAS, re HTML5...meant to be more specific there
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:51): say, a html5 game for example, written using a good OOP class structure, rendered to the canvas
f2fc9a4df1a1bfb441133cbe51407f7b (01:53): impactjs is pretty good
f2fc9a4df1a1bfb441133cbe51407f7b (01:53): but its 100$
f2fc9a4df1a1bfb441133cbe51407f7b (01:53): akihabara is free but its a mess
f2fc9a4df1a1bfb441133cbe51407f7b (01:53): I'm working on https://github.com/WhenRaptorsAttack/Jixel
f2fc9a4df1a1bfb441133cbe51407f7b (01:53): which is a port of flixel
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:53): my favourite district...warrants a look for that reason alone
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:54): nice :)
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:54): I'm looking to port my own framework actually, but not liking the thought of doing it all in np++
7ce5148c5adbb308a403c3cc3a8be5e8 (01:55): flixel would do great in html5 though

0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:56): 3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d just a fyi, the 20 years thing was, at one point, the predicted time when the spec for this stuff would be finalized by the W3C
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:56): but as history has shown, people use the technologies long before finalization
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:56): yes, which causes the misuse which has plagued the web since the early days
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:57): take forever to put out a spec, people use it partially + bastardize the rest, Dead-Before-Arrival
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:57): the web is such a dirty dirty platform
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:57): you should be going back and revising anyway
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:57): left web dev in '99 to do lower level work and is now back
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:57): keep an eye on where things are going, realign with that
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:58): and yes vendor prefixes for css3 stuff feels dirty to a lot of people
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:58): but you can easily go in and remove those quickly and be back on square one
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (01:58): i didn't say anything about vendor prefixes, you did
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:59): a lot of the html tags that are new are pretty set in stone too
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (01:59): i doubt there will be drastic changes to them between now and then
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (02:01): yea i mean, i've heard all that before
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (02:01): makes the pool water no less filthy
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (02:12): you can use whatever you want, i know what I intend to use regularly in the near future :D

3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (03:19): hey guys, why can html elements have multiple classes applied? it's like multiple inheritance kinda, which we all know to suck
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (03:24): 3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d: css classes have nothing to do with object oriented programming
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (03:38): <3 the fact that multiple classes are possible
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (03:47): do you guys build sites to use 100% of width? or do you do the 'center a document's width' thing?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (03:49): i tend to stick to a container 960px wide
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:12): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17: but what about scaling interfaces and people running 30" displays?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:13): if i plan to go smaller, it'd be a case of using media queries
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:13): if it's a case of going bigger, i probably wouldn't scale up the site, and from what i understand, most people don't do full screen on huge displays
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:13): ?g css media queries
38e5971429bb0f30aa410ac1ae0bb9a9 (04:13): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17, Media Queries - http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-mediaqueries/
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:14): there ya go
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:14): media queries, ok got it. coulda also said style sheet media attr correct?
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:16): why 960? figure most ppl have 1024 width?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:17): little bit of left/right padding
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:17): don't need the content butting up against the side of the browser window
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:17): yea, i remember when we went from 760 to that back in the day
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:17): this way each side gets 32px
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:17): (i personally used 20px of margin on each side)
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:18): 976 could be nice though
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:18): give 24 for each side
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:18): go with whatever you want :)
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:18): we should continue to discuss this
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:19): 960 becaome popular with the 960.gs system
38e5971429bb0f30aa410ac1ae0bb9a9 (04:19): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17, Category: 960.gs tutorials - http://www.gridsystemgenerator.com/category/resources/grid-system-tutorials/960-gs-tutorials/
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:19): damn, that didn't work out quite like i hoped :D
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:21): it's all preference really
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:21): well, what i did always like about 960 was that it was 480 * 2
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:21): 240 120 60 30 15 are numbers that feel nice to me
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:21): easily divisible
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:22): but then again, i also always enjoy base 10 and 2 systems
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:22): and the 15 minimum granularity i actually enjoy. coarse granularity is perfect for, as you said, grid systems
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:25): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17: what do you think?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:26): i don't get in on that half of the site process too much at the moment
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:26): i'm mostly handed a PSD and told "make this work in Wordpress"
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:28): oh. so out of curiosity, what's your workflow to do that? make a psd work in wordpress
bdedc97e25dde1328bae6e2d092691c8 (04:29): Static-width layouts work well because page zoom on non-IE browsers does a great job
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:29): determine what parts need to be images, extract those out of the psd
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:29): figure out containers needed
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:30): slowly pull out hair as i look at all of the potential z-index issues i'll be seeing
bdedc97e25dde1328bae6e2d092691c8 (04:30): The best layouts can deal with being static width and convert to 100% width when the zoom level is high
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:30): the past few "big" projects have had things jutting out the sides of containers
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:30): and too much love for paperclips + paper behind it
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:32): btw what do you mean by 'containers'? like, DIV?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:32): divs/articles/headers/footers/sections/asides
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:33): use the latter ones when possible, divs for when the latter isn't the right fit
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:35): use the html5shiv for the IE dinosaurs, set them to display: block in css for all of the browsers for the time being
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:44): dunno what you meant by the last sentence, but it reminds me of what i read about 'css resetting'
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (04:45): or an article from a day ago that talked about providing 'safe defaults' for html tags
38e5971429bb0f30aa410ac1ae0bb9a9 (04:46): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17, html5shiv - Project Hosting on Google Code - http://code.google.com/p/html5shiv/
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (04:46): http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/html-css-techniques/how-to-make-all-browsers-render-html5-mark-up-correctly-even-ie6/
